references: Our detailed proof of Theorem 2 is in Appendix E. We successfully prove that the actual effect of RAG can be predicted at token level. The gap between values of benefit and detriment in Equation 11 indicates how much greater the benefit is than the detriment, which is the actual effect of RAG. This gap is approximately positively correlated with the representation similarity, which is the value that can be predicted (details in Section 3). Besides, Equation 11 is derived from the token level prediction (p⁢(xi|R,x1:i−1)𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑅subscript𝑥:1𝑖1p(x_{i}|R,x_{1:i-1})italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )), this shows that the actual effect of RAG can be predicted at token level by 1D1𝐷\frac{1}{D}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_D end_ARG. Section 3 introduces our detailed method to achieve this in practical applications.

S4.T1.24.24.caption: Table 1: Performance on determining the value order between benefit and detriment at token level. Significant test with p-value ≤0.05absent0.05\leq 0.05≤ 0.05 compared with all baselines are denoted as ‘+++’.
references:
Primary experiment.
Table 1 shows that our X-RAG achieves better performance in determining the value order between benefit and detriment at token level in RAG than baselines across different tasks and LLMs. Baselines determine the value order by detecting the degree of hallucination while our X-RAG can directly compare the benefit and detriment based on our theoretical analysis, which is more fundamental so it performs better. In this experiment, we construct the test sample by selecting the token a𝑎aitalic_a generated by RAG that is different from the token b𝑏bitalic_b generated by pure LLM given the same and accurate prefix (Teacher-Forcing). If the token of RAG (a𝑎aitalic_a) is correct and the token of pure LLM (b𝑏bitalic_b) is wrong, the label is 1111 means that the benefit is greater than the detriment. Otherwise, the detriment is greater than the benefit and the label is 00. We use this principle to traverse the second half of the tokens of each sample in the entire dataset to construct the test dataset.

S4.T2.6.1.caption: Table 2: Accuracy on open-domain Q&A given the retrieved texts containing different ratios (0%percent00\%0 % to 100%percent100100\%100 %) of hard negative passages (irrelevant but are ranked in top-10 by retrieval model). Our X-RAG does not need any training or additional modules while baselines need.
references:
Experiment on Open-domain Q&A. This experiment is under the practical autoregressive generation setting for open-domain Q&A.
Table 2 shows that in RAG given the retrieved texts with various qualities, our X-RAG does not need any additional modules or training and outperforms the strong baselines that need additional filters or training LLMs. This means our X-RAG achieves a better trade-off between benefit and detriment in RAG, avoiding detriment while securing benefit. It is because our theoretical analysis helps us propose a more fundamental method in measuring value order between benefit and detriment at token level. Baselines do not have theoretical support, so they require more additional overhead. In this experiment, we adjust the radio of irrelevant passages in the retrieved passage list from 0%percent00\%0 % to 100%percent100100\%100 %, which can simulate the degree of noise in the retrieved texts. Since Open-domain Q&A is a short-form task, we calculate the accuracy by judging whether the ground truth appears exactly in the generated texts (Cover-EM Rosset et al. (2020)). LLM in this is LLaMA-2-7B.

(72)
references:
which means that 1𝒟=1ℳ1𝒟1ℳ\frac{1}{\mathcal{D}}=\frac{1}{\mathcal{M}}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG caligraphic_M end_ARG is an important dividing point. When 1𝒟=1ℳ1𝒟1ℳ\frac{1}{\mathcal{D}}=\frac{1}{\mathcal{M}}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG caligraphic_M end_ARG, we can get that benefit is equal to detriment and KL(pR(r)∥p(r|z))−KL(pR(r)∥p(r|z∗))=0\text{KL}(p_{R}(r)\|p(r|z))-\text{KL}(p_{R}(r)\|p(r|z^{*}))=0KL ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) ∥ italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z ) ) - KL ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) ∥ italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) = 0. Equation 72 indicates that the gap between values of benefit and detriment (KL(pR(r)∥p(r|z))−KL(pR(r)∥p(r|z∗))\text{KL}(p_{R}(r)\|p(r|z))-\text{KL}(p_{R}(r)\|p(r|z^{*}))KL ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) ∥ italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z ) ) - KL ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) ∥ italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) )) is approximately positively correlated with 1𝒟1𝒟\frac{1}{\mathcal{D}}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG. Therefore, when 1𝒟>1ℳ1𝒟1ℳ\frac{1}{\mathcal{D}}>\frac{1}{\mathcal{M}}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG > divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG caligraphic_M end_ARG we can get that benefit outweighs detriment (KL(pR(r)∥p(r|z))−KL(pR(r)∥p(r|z∗))>0\text{KL}(p_{R}(r)\|p(r|z))-\text{KL}(p_{R}(r)\|p(r|z^{*}))>0KL ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) ∥ italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z ) ) - KL ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) ∥ italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) > 0). When 1𝒟<1ℳ1𝒟1ℳ\frac{1}{\mathcal{D}}<\frac{1}{\mathcal{M}}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG < divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG caligraphic_M end_ARG we can get that detriment outweighs benefit (KL(pR(r)∥p(r|z))−KL(pR(r)∥p(r|z∗))<0\text{KL}(p_{R}(r)\|p(r|z))-\text{KL}(p_{R}(r)\|p(r|z^{*}))<0KL ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) ∥ italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z ) ) - KL ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) ∥ italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) < 0). Now the proof of Theorem 3 has been finished.
∎
